topic.title: Ethernet Client Blocking Example

body.p: The SDK and NMS managed approaches to assigning SERDES and Ethernet PHY resources are intended to offer the flexibility required for typical optic module population scenarios as per the examples provided in the previous sections. The device does offer the ability to build cards that have multiple optics cages with a subset of them being populated at any given time that could lead to the need for rearrangement of Ethernet clients should Ethernet PHY channels required by a higher rate Ethernet client be occupied by a lower rate Ethernet client. For example, a card could provide optics cages for 6 x 100 GbE clients and 1 x 400 GbE client. Not all cages could be in use at the same time as the Ethernet subsystem supports up to 600G of Ethernet processing . Therefore, a card with the 6 x 100 GbE clients provisioned would need to de-provision four of the 100 GbE clients to provision the 400 GbE. The 100 GbE clients that would need to be de-provisioned would be dictated by the Ethernet PHY channels that are occupied by the 100 GbE clients and required for the 400 GbE client.

This section provides an example of a blocking scenario that would require re-arrangement. The example may be useful for providing guidance in end-user documentation for blocking and non-blocking scenarios. For example, end user documentation may denote two of the 100 GbE optics cages as non-blocking resources and four of the 100 GbE optics cages as a blocking resource that would need to be de-provisioned when a 400 GbE client is provisioned. Alternatively, with the NMS managed assignment of Ethernet PHY channel method, the first two 100 GbE clients that are populated could be assigned Ethernet PHY channels by the NMS that do not occupy the Ethernet PHY channels required by the 400 GbE client and end user documentation may state the first two 100 GbE clients provisioned are non-blocking with any subsequent 100 GbE that is populated blocks provisioning of the 400GE.

Figure 1 illustrates an Ethernet client card example with a QSFP-DD optics cage for 400GE and six QSFP28 cages for six 100GE clients. On day 1, the six 100GE optics are populated and the 400GE is not populated.

fig.title: QSFP-DD + 6 x QSFP28 Ethernet Provisioning Example - Day 1

body.p: On day 2, 4 x 100GE Ethernet clients have been de-provisioned as illustrated in Figure 2.

fig.title: QSFP-DD + 6 x QSFP28 Ethernet Provisioning Example - Day 2

body.p: On day 3, 200G of the 600G Ethernet subsystem capacity is allocated and 400G is available for provisioning. Provisioning the 400GE requires use of Ethernet PHY channel addresses 0 to 15 as per the rules defined in Ethernet Client PHY Channel Assignment and Related SERDES Selection Rules but channels 0-3 are occupied by the 100GE from transceiver 2. To free up the channels for use by the 400GE client, the 100GE from transceiver 2 is de-provisioned and re-provisioned using available channels 20 to 23 as illustrated in Figure 3.

fig.title: QSFP-DD + 6 x QSFP28 Ethernet Provisioning Example - Day 3
